channel.title: git on My Hugo
channel.description: Recent content in git on My Hugo

item.title: Push Exercise
item.description: Plan export EX=~/codex/git export REPO=$EX/repo mkdir -p $REPO Setup Root Repo $ cd $REPO $ mkdir adam $ cd adam $ git init --bare $ cd $EX $ git clone $REPO/adam $ # add something and make 1st commit $ cat > readme $ mkdir books $ cat > books/chap1 $ git add readme books $ git commit -m 'fist commit' $ # push to repo $ git push Create A clone of Root Repo $ cd $REPO $ git clone adam dave --bare $ cd dave $ git log commit eb9ad62b26faf73c024e5c15b0b39bf68d82f7be Author: Jason Zou <jzou2000@gmail.

item.title: Setup Git Upstream
item.description: Create An Upstream Repo There are two types of repositories: bare: repositories do not have a working copy and you can push to them, for example, repositories that you get in github. Bare repositories work as upstreams. non-bare: repositories that you are working on, with a working copy. Repositories that you clone or init are non-bare by default. You can’t (by default) and shouldn’t push to non-bare repos. Note: technically, you can push to a non-bare repo (see below), but that is not a common practice.
